Invariants for subsetting and subassignment

Source: vignettes/invariants.Rmd
invariants.Rmd

This vignette is an attempt to define invariants in the behavior of $, [[ and [, and their assignment counterparts $<-, [[<- and [<-. For each invariant an example is given. The subsetting and subassignment articles give a comprehensive overview.

library(tibble)
new_df <- function() {
  df <- data.frame(a = 1:4)
  df$b <- letters[5:8]
  df$cd <- list(9, 10:11, 12:14, "text")
  df
}
new_tbl <- function() {
  as_tibble(new_df())
}

Results of the same code for data frames and tibbles are presented side by side:

new_df()
#>   a b         cd
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
new_tbl()
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

In the following, if the results are identical (after converting to a data frame if necessary), only the tibble result is shown, as in the example below. This allows to spot differences easier.

new_tbl()
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

Subsetting operations are read-only. The same objects are reused in all examples:

df <- new_df()
tbl <- new_tbl()

We’re also showing examples with hierarchical columns containting a data frame or a matrix where appropriate:

new_tbl2 <- function() {
  tibble(
    e = tbl,
    f = diag(4)
  )
}
new_df2 <- function() {
  df2 <- new_tbl2()
  class(df2) <- "data.frame"
  class(df2$e) <- "data.frame"
  df2
}
df2 <- new_df2()
tbl2 <- new_tbl2()
new_tbl()
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

For subassignment, we need a fresh copy of the data for each test. The with_*() functions allow for a more concise notation (with_tbl() and with_*2() omitted here for brevity):

with_df <- function(code, verbose = FALSE) {
  code <- rlang::enexpr(code)
  
  full_code <- rlang::quo({
    df <- new_df()
    !!code
    df
  })
  if (verbose) rlang::expr_print(rlang::quo_get_expr(full_code))
  rlang::eval_tidy(full_code)
}

This function takes an assignment expression and executes it on a fresh copy of the data. The first example prints what’s really executed, further examples omit this output.

with_df(df$a <- rev(df$a), verbose = TRUE)
#> {
#>   df <- new_df()
#>   df$a <- rev(df$a)
#>   df
#> }
#>   a b         cd
#> 1 4 e          9
#> 2 3 f     10, 11
#> 3 2 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 1 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl$a <- rev(tbl$a), verbose = TRUE)
#> {
#>   tbl <- new_tbl()
#>   tbl$a <- rev(tbl$a)
#>   tbl
#> }
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     4 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     3 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     2 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     1 h     <chr [1]>

Subsetting and subassignment

[[ requires scalar indexes

tbl[[1]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
df[[1:2]]
#> [1] 2
 
tbl[[1:2]]
#> Warning: Calling `[[` with a vector
#> of length 2 (recursive subsetting)
#> is deprecated and will eventually be
#> converted to an error.
#> [1] 2
 
df[[1:3]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, i, exact =
#> exact): recursive indexing failed at
#> level 2
 
tbl[[1:3]]
#> `j` must have size 1, not size 3.
 
tbl[[1, 1]]
#> [1] 1
 
df[[1:2, 1]]
#> Error in col[[i, exact = exact]]:
#> attempt to select more than one
#> element in vectorIndex
 
tbl[[1:2, 1]]
#> `i` must have size 1, not size 2.
 
df[[1, 1:2]]
#> [1] 2
 
tbl[[1, 1:2]]
#> `j` must have size 1, not size 2.
 
df[[1:2, 1:2]]
#> Error in col[[i, exact = exact]]:
#> attempt to select more than one
#> element in vectorIndex
 
tbl[[1:2, 1:2]]
#> `j` must have size 1, not size 2.
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[1:2]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: more
#> elements supplied than there are to
#> replace
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:2]] <- 0)
#> `j` must have size 1, not size 2.
 
with_df(df[[1:3]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-`(`*tmp*`, i, value =
#> value): recursive indexing failed at
#> level 2
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:3]] <- 0)
#> `j` must have size 1, not size 3.
 
with_df(df[[1, 1]] <- 0)
#>   a b         cd
#> 1 0 e          9
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[1:2, 1]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1:2, 1, value = 0): only a single
#> element should be replaced
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:2, 1]] <- 0)
#> `i` must have size 1, not size 2.
 
with_df(df[[1, 1:2]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1, 1:2, value = 0): only a single
#> element should be replaced
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 1:2]] <- 0)
#> Warning: Calling `[[` with a vector
#> of length 2 (recursive subsetting)
#> is deprecated and will eventually be
#> converted to an error.
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[1:2, 1:2]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1:2, 1:2, value = 0): only a single
#> element should be replaced
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:2, 1:2]] <- 0)
#> `i` must have size 1, not size 2.

x[[j]] is equivalent to unwrap(x[j]).

unwrap <- function(x) {
  unclass(x)[[1]]
}
tbl[[1]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
unwrap(tbl[1])
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[[3]]
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
unwrap(tbl[3])
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
tbl2[[1]]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
unwrap(tbl2[1])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
tbl2[[2]]
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    1    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    1    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    1
 
unwrap(tbl2[2])
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    1    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    1    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    1

Corollary: x[j] and x[[j]] can be used interchangeably on the LHS or RHS of an assignment for the four principal column types:

  • atomic: df[[1]]
  • list: df[[3]]
  • data frame: df2[[1]]
  • matrix: df2[[2]] 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- tbl[[3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   a         b     cd       
#> * <list>    <chr> <list>   
#> 1 <dbl [1]> e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 <int [2]> f     <int [2]>
#> 3 <int [3]> g     <int [3]>
#> 4 <chr [1]> h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- tbl2[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>     a$a $b    $cd       b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]> e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]> f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]> g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]> h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- tbl2[[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   a[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] b     cd      
#> * <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <list>  
#> 1     1     0     0     0 e     <dbl [1…
#> 2     0     1     0     0 f     <int [2…
#> 3     0     0     1     0 g     <int [3…
#> 4     0     0     0     1 h     <chr [1…
 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- list(tbl[[3]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   a         b     cd       
#> * <list>    <chr> <list>   
#> 1 <dbl [1]> e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 <int [2]> f     <int [2]>
#> 3 <int [3]> g     <int [3]>
#> 4 <chr [1]> h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- list(tbl2[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>     a$a $b    $cd       b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]> e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]> f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]> g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]> h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- list(tbl2[[2]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   a[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] b     cd      
#> * <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <list>  
#> 1     1     0     0     0 e     <dbl [1…
#> 2     0     1     0     0 f     <int [2…
#> 3     0     0     1     0 g     <int [3…
#> 4     0     0     0     1 h     <chr [1…
 
with_tbl(tbl[[3]] <- tbl[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b        cd
#> * <int> <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 e         1
#> 2     2 f         2
#> 3     3 g         3
#> 4     4 h         4
 
with_tbl(tbl[[3]] <- tbl2[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b      cd$a $b    $cd      
#> * <int> <chr> <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e         1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f         2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g         3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h         4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[3]] <- tbl2[[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <int> <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e          1     0     0     0
#> 2     2 f          0     1     0     0
#> 3     3 g          0     0     1     0
#> 4     4 h          0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl(tbl[3] <- list(tbl[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b        cd
#> * <int> <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 e         1
#> 2     2 f         2
#> 3     3 g         3
#> 4     4 h         4
 
with_tbl(tbl[3] <- list(tbl2[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b      cd$a $b    $cd      
#> * <int> <chr> <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e         1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f         2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g         3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h         4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[3] <- list(tbl2[[2]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <int> <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e          1     0     0     0
#> 2     2 f          0     1     0     0
#> 3     3 g          0     0     1     0
#> 4     4 h          0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1]] <- tbl[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       e f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1     1     0     0     0
#> 2     2     0     1     0     0
#> 3     3     0     0     1     0
#> 4     4     0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1]] <- tbl[[3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   e         f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <list>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 <dbl [1]>     1     0     0     0
#> 2 <int [2]>     0     1     0     0
#> 3 <int [3]>     0     0     1     0
#> 4 <chr [1]>     0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1]] <- tbl2[[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   e[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] f[,1]  [,2]
#> * <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1     0     0     0     1     0
#> 2     0     1     0     0     0     1
#> 3     0     0     1     0     0     0
#> 4     0     0     0     1     0     0
#> # … with 2 more variables: [,3] <dbl>,
#> #   [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1] <- list(tbl[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       e f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1     1     0     0     0
#> 2     2     0     1     0     0
#> 3     3     0     0     1     0
#> 4     4     0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1] <- list(tbl[[3]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   e         f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#> * <list>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 <dbl [1]>     1     0     0     0
#> 2 <int [2]>     0     1     0     0
#> 3 <int [3]>     0     0     1     0
#> 4 <chr [1]>     0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1] <- list(tbl2[[2]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   e[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] f[,1]  [,2]
#> * <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1     0     0     0     1     0
#> 2     0     1     0     0     0     1
#> 3     0     0     1     0     0     0
#> 4     0     0     0     1     0     0
#> # … with 2 more variables: [,3] <dbl>,
#> #   [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- tbl[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd           f
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     1
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     2
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     3
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- tbl[[3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd       f        
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]> <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]> <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]> <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]> <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- tbl2[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd       f$a $b    $cd   
#> * <int> <chr> <list>  <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl […     1 e     <dbl …
#> 2     2 f     <int […     2 f     <int …
#> 3     3 g     <int […     3 g     <int …
#> 4     4 h     <chr […     4 h     <chr …
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2] <- list(tbl[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd           f
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     1
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     2
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     3
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2] <- list(tbl[[3]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd       f        
#> * <int> <chr> <list>    <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]> <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]> <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]> <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]> <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2] <- list(tbl2[[1]]))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd       f$a $b    $cd   
#> * <int> <chr> <list>  <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl […     1 e     <dbl …
#> 2     2 f     <int […     2 f     <int …
#> 3     3 g     <int […     3 g     <int …
#> 4     4 h     <chr […     4 h     <chr …

x[[i, j]] is equivalent to x[i, ][[j]].

tbl[[1, 1]]
#> [1] 1
 
tbl[1, ][[1]]
#> [1] 1
 
df[[1, 3]]
#> [1] 9
 
tbl[[1, 3]]
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
 
tbl[1, ][[3]]
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
 
df2[[1, 1]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl2[[1, 1]]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
tbl2[1, ][[1]]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
df2[[1, 2]]
#> [1] 1
 
tbl2[[1, 2]]
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
 
tbl2[1, ][[2]]
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0

Corollary: x[[i, j]] and x[i, ][[j]] can be used interchangeably on the LHS or RHS of an assignment for the four principal column types:

  • atomic: df[[1]]
  • list: df[[3]]
  • data frame: df2[[1]]
  • matrix: df2[[2]] 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 1]] <- tbl[[2, 1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     2 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1, ][[1]] <- tbl[2, ][[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     2 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 3]] <- tbl[[2, 3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <int [2]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1, ][[3]] <- tbl[2, ][[3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <int [2]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df2(df2[[1, 1]] <- df2[[2, 1]])
#>   e.a e.b       e.cd f.1 f.2 f.3 f.4
#> 1   e   e          9   1   0   0   0
#> 2   f   f     10, 11   0   1   0   0
#> 3   g   g 12, 13, 14   0   0   1   0
#> 4   h   h       text   0   0   0   1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1, 1]] <- tbl2[[2, 1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd      f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     2 f     <int [2…     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2…     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3…     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1…     0     0     0
#> # … with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1, ][[1]] <- tbl2[2, ][[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd      f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     2 f     <int [2…     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2…     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3…     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1…     0     0     0
#> # … with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[[1, 2]] <- df2[[2, 2]])
#>   e.a e.b       e.cd f.1 f.2 f.3 f.4
#> 1   1   e          9   0   0   0   0
#> 2   2   f     10, 11   0   1   0   0
#> 3   3   g 12, 13, 14   0   0   1   0
#> 4   4   h       text   0   0   0   1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1, 2]] <- tbl2[[2, 2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd      f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1…     0     1     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2…     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3…     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1…     0     0     0
#> # … with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1, ][[2]] <- tbl2[2, ][[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>     e$a $b    $cd      f[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#> * <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1…     0     1     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2…     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3…     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1…     0     0     0
#> # … with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>

x$name is equivalent to x[["name"]].

tbl$a
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[["a"]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl$cd
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
tbl[["cd"]]
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
tbl2$e
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
tbl2[["e"]]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       a b     cd       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
tbl2$f
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    1    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    1    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    1
 
tbl2[["f"]]
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    0    0    0
#> [2,]    0    1    0    0
#> [3,]    0    0    1    0
#> [4,]    0    0    0    1

Corollary: $ does not implement partial matching.

df$c
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
tbl$c
#> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised
#> column: `c`.
#> NULL
 
df[["c"]]
#> NULL
 
tbl[["c"]]
#> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised
#> column: `c`.
#> NULL
 
tbl$c <- 0
 
tbl[["c"]] <- 0

Subsetting

x[[j]] always returns an object of length nrow(x).

FIXME.

Corollary: x[[i, j]] always returns an object of length 1 (by definition of x[[1, j]]).

[ always returns a tibble.

df[, 1]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[, 1]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 1
#>       a
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
#> 2     2
#> 3     3
#> 4     4
 
tbl[1, ]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 4
#>       a b     cd            c
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
 
df[1, 1]
#> [1] 1
 
tbl[1, 1]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>       a
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
 
tbl[, 1, drop = FALSE]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 1
#>       a
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
#> 2     2
#> 3     3
#> 4     4
 
tbl[1, , drop = FALSE]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 4
#>       a b     cd            c
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
 
tbl[1, 1, drop = FALSE]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>       a
#>   <int>
#> 1     1

Exception: drop = TRUE returns a vector when subsetting a single column with two-dimensional indexing, this is for backward compatibility with code that uses an explicit drop = TRUE to access columns as vectors.

tbl[, 1, drop = TRUE]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
df[1, , drop = TRUE]
#> $a
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $b
#> [1] "e"
#> 
#> $cd
#> $cd[[1]]
#> [1] 9
 
tbl[1, , drop = TRUE]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 4
#>       a b     cd            c
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
 
tbl[1, 1, drop = TRUE]
#> [1] 1

Dimensions are defined by i and j.

The dimensions after [ and [[ are given by the length of vec_as_index(i) and vec_as_index(j).

dim(df[1, 1])
#> NULL
 
dim(tbl[1, 1])
#> [1] 1 1
 
dim(tbl[1:3, 1:2])
#> [1] 3 2
 
dim(tbl[TRUE, c("b", "cd")])
#> [1] 4 2
 
dim(tbl[-3, -2])
#> [1] 3 3

Corollary: Missing dimensions are extended to an index vector along the rows or columns, respectively (with rlib/vctrs#547).

dim(tbl[])
#> [1] 4 4
 
dim(tbl[,])
#> [1] 4 4
 
dim(tbl[1, ])
#> [1] 1 4
 
dim(df[, 1])
#> NULL
 
dim(tbl[, 1])
#> [1] 4 1

Corollary: Out-of-bounds indexing is not supported (but for compatibility reasons only a warning is issued for indexing beyond the number of rows).

dim(df[5, ])
#> [1] 1 3
 
dim(tbl[5, ])
#> Warning: Row indexes must be between
#> 0 and the number of rows. Use `NA` as
#> row index to obtain a row full of `NA`
#> values.
#> [1] 1 4
 
dim(df[, 4])
#> Error in `[.data.frame`(df, , 4):
#> undefined columns selected
 
dim(tbl[, 4])
#> [1] 4 1

Exception: NA indexing is supported for rows only.

tbl[NA_integer_, ]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 4
#>       a b     cd         c
#>   <int> <chr> <list> <dbl>
#> 1    NA <NA>  <NULL>    NA
 
df[, NA_integer_]
#> Error in `[.data.frame`(df, ,
#> NA_integer_): undefined columns
#> selected
 
tbl[, NA_integer_]
#> Can't use numeric NA as column index
#> with `[`.

Subassignment

Only sizes 1 are recycled.

Columns don’t have inner names.

with_df(df$x <- c(a = 4, b = 3, c = 2, d = 1))$x
#> [1] 4 3 2 1
 
with_tbl(tbl$x <- c(a = 4, b = 3, c = 2, d = 1))$x
#> a b c d 
#> 4 3 2 1
 
with_tbl(tbl$x <- list(a = 4, b = 3, c = 2, d = 1))$x
#> $a
#> [1] 4
#> 
#> $b
#> [1] 3
#> 
#> $c
#> [1] 2
#> 
#> $d
#> [1] 1

FIXME

  • [<-, [[<- and $<- can create new columns
    • only if using named column index or if the rhs is a data frame specifying the names of the new columns
    • only if updating entire columns (i is missing)
  • [<- can create new rows
    • only right at the end of the existing data
  • [<-, [[<- and $<- can change the type of an existing column
    • only if updating entire columns (i is missing), otherwise the data must be of the same type
  • For updating a subset of rows, only updating existing columns is supported
  • For updating more than one column, the rhs must be either
    • a scalar (recycled)
    • a vector sized same as the number of rows (new value for all columns)
    • a data frame with the same column names as the target names
  • Multiple columns require a data frame at the rhs

  • Subsetting
  • Subassignment

tibble is a part of the tidyverse, an ecosystem of packages designed with common APIs and a shared philosophy. Learn more at tidyverse.org.
